quote: Lights.
Are you sure re-opening the   restaurant is a good idea?
Jake, it's been four days since   the power outage... have you seen   any Dominion invasion fleet?
No.
Neither have I.
Besides, at my age, I don't have   time to waste sitting at home   being bored.
There's hardly anyone out on the   street. You're not going to have   any customers.
I've got plenty of customers.   Just look outside.
All I see are security officers.
And I bet not one of them's had a   good meal in four days. Now do   your grandfather a favor... and   start chopping the okra.

I don't like this. The more I   read Starfleet's reports on the   sabotage of the power relays, the   more unanswered questions I have.       How were the changelings able to   infiltrate the Division of   Planetary operations? Where did   they get the codes for the   Division's computer control   network? And how did they manage   to overload every power relay on   Earth at the same time?
Captain, have you ever heard of a   group called Red Squad?
They're an elite team of Starfleet   cadets. According to Nog, every   student at the Academy wants to be   a part of it.
That explains it.
Explains what?
According to this transporter log,   a group called Red Squad was   beamed back to Starfleet Academy   twenty-six minutes after the State   of Emergency was declared.
That's strange. During the   blackout, Starfleet mobilized   hundreds of units. Why would they   have demobilized Red Squad?
That's why I brought it up. But   if they're cadets... I suppose   Starfleet wanted to get them out   of harm's way.
If that's true, then how do you   explain this...    (finds what he was    looking for)   Three hours later Starfleet   Command issued an order assigning   the entire Corps of Cadets to   field duty.
Which means they weren't bringing   Red Squad home to protect them.
So the question is... why   demobilize Red Squad only to   mobilize them again three hours   later?
Captain Sisko, is there something   I can do for you?
scene: 4    INT. SISKO'S TEMPORARY OFFICE - DAY - LATER (OPTICAL)

quote: I need to talk to you about Red   Squad.
scene: 4    INT. SISKO'S TEMPORARY OFFICE - DAY - LATER (OPTICAL)

quote: Go on.
scene: 4    INT. SISKO'S TEMPORARY OFFICE - DAY - LATER (OPTICAL)

quote: Are you aware that there's a   transporter record of Red Squad   being returned to the Academy not   long after the power outage?
scene: 4    INT. SISKO'S TEMPORARY OFFICE - DAY - LATER (OPTICAL)

quote: Are you saying that's in the   official records?
scene: 4    INT. SISKO'S TEMPORARY OFFICE - DAY - LATER (OPTICAL)

quote: That's right.
scene: 4    INT. SISKO'S TEMPORARY OFFICE - DAY - LATER (OPTICAL)

quote: Is this a secure line?
scene: 4    INT. SISKO'S TEMPORARY OFFICE - DAY - LATER (OPTICAL)

quote: It is at my end.
scene: 4    INT. SISKO'S TEMPORARY OFFICE - DAY - LATER (OPTICAL)

quote: One moment.
scene: 4    INT. SISKO'S TEMPORARY OFFICE - DAY - LATER (OPTICAL)

quote: Sorry, Captain. But I think   you'll agree, this is a time for   caution.
scene: 4    INT. SISKO'S TEMPORARY OFFICE - DAY - LATER (OPTICAL)

quote: Absolutely.
scene: 4    INT. SISKO'S TEMPORARY OFFICE - DAY - LATER (OPTICAL)

quote: Does Admiral Leyton know about   this report?
scene: 4    INT. SISKO'S TEMPORARY OFFICE - DAY - LATER (OPTICAL)

quote: He hasn't mentioned it to me.
scene: 4    INT. SISKO'S TEMPORARY OFFICE - DAY - LATER (OPTICAL)

quote: Listen to me, Captain. I want   that record erased before anyone   else sees it. Is that understood?
scene: 4    INT. SISKO'S TEMPORARY OFFICE - DAY - LATER (OPTICAL)

quote: I'll take care of it immediately.
scene: 4    INT. SISKO'S TEMPORARY OFFICE - DAY - LATER (OPTICAL)

quote: Good. That report could cause us   a lot of trouble. I'm glad you   spotted it.
scene: 4    INT. SISKO'S TEMPORARY OFFICE - DAY - LATER (OPTICAL)

quote: So am I. I'd hate to see the   members of Red Squad get into any   trouble.
scene: 4    INT. SISKO'S TEMPORARY OFFICE - DAY - LATER (OPTICAL)

quote: They're fine young men and women.   When Leyton talked to me about   using them, I thought it was a   mistake... but I have to admit,   they performed their mission   admirably.       I appreciate your call, Captain.   I'm in your debt.
scene: 4    INT. SISKO'S TEMPORARY OFFICE - DAY - LATER (OPTICAL)

quote: Well, that certainly raised more   questions than it answered.
scene: 4    INT. SISKO'S TEMPORARY OFFICE - DAY - LATER (OPTICAL)

quote: What did I tell you? As human as   I ever was.
You're looking pretty jovial   today.
Is there a problem with that?
It's just... you weren't so happy   about being tested a few days ago.
That was before the changelings   sabotaged the power grid.
I don't understand you. When I   didn't want to be tested you made   it an issue, and now that I'm   cooperating you're still not   satisfied.
It's not you, Dad.
Then what is it?
I'm not sure.       They look tired.
I'm not surprised. Now that the   blood screenings have been widened   to include the general public,   they've been working around the   clock.
Besides, they're not the only ones   who look tired.
Captain, Jake said you wanted to   see me.
Yes, I do.
You two talk.       I'll go chill some   tube grubs.
What can I do for you, sir?
It's about Red Squad.
Red Squad? Did you get me in?
Not just yet.
Too bad. Those guys are the best.   They're the only people I know who   aren't afraid of the Dominion.
Why's that?
I don't know. They're not scared   of anything, I guess.
You seem to know them pretty well.
Jake said I should try to get to   know them better. Show them I'm   a good guy. And so far it seems   to be working.       The truth is, I think they only   like me because I know you.
Is that so?
You're kind of their hero. The   man at the front line in the war   with the Dominion.
I'd like to meet some of these   cadets. You think you could   introduce me to one of them?
I'm sorry. I can't do that, sir.       The names of Red Squad members are   supposed to be secret.
But you know who they are.
It's not easy keeping secrets from   a Ferengi. But I feel funny about   telling anyone else. Besides, if   they found out I told you who they   were, I'd never get in.
Cadet, you're obviously under the   mistaken impression that I'm   asking you a favor. I want a   name, and I want it now. And that   is an order. Understood, Mister   Nog?
Yes, sir.
Cadet Shepard reporting as   ordered, Captain.
Shepard, Riley Aldrin, Starfleet   Service number c-nine-five-three-   oh-four-six-nine-nine-four-two-   seven, a third year student at   Starfleet Academy with a specialty   in tactical operations.
Yes, sir.
Cadet, I've been reviewing a   record of Red Squad's activities   on the night of the twenty-third.   The night of the power outage.
Record, sir? We were told that   there wasn't going to be any   written record...
Are you contradicting me, cadet?
No, sir.
Good. Now, who told you there   wasn't going to be a written   record?
The briefing officer, sir.
I want that officer's name.
She didn't give her name, sir.   But she told us that there would   be no record of our actions. That   our role would have to go   unrecognized, at least for now.
Maybe if you'd done your job   better, it would have.       But you fouled it up, didn't you?   You cadets did some sloppy work...   some damn sloppy work.
With all due respect, sir...   that's not true, sir. The mission   went perfectly. If anything, it   was easier than the simulations.
Son, if you think you can protect   your hide by lying to me, you'd   better forget it. Mistakes were   made, and I will find out who's   responsible.
I'm not lying to you, sir. I was   there. I was at Planetary   Operations the whole time. If   anything had gone wrong, I   would've known about it.
Is that so?
All right, cadet. Let's go over   this step-by-step from the time of   your mission deployment until your   return to base...       ... at nineteen forty-seven hours   PST on the twenty-third.
Yes, sir. We assembled on the   Eastern Quad at seventeen hundred   hours on the evening of the twenty-   third.
By "we" I assume you mean Red   Squad.

Yes, sir. After assembly we were   beamed aboard the Lakota. Once   aboard we received our equipment   and the necessary codes, and were   transported directly to the   Division of Planetary Operations   in Lisbon.
At what time?
It was oh-four hundred hours   exactly. Local time of course.
Go on, cadet.

Our contact inside the DPO gave us   access to their computer control   network. From there we used the   access codes we were given,   bypassed the security lockouts,   and downloaded the disordering   protocols into the network.
And from there the protocols   spread to every power relay on the   planet.
It was a pretty, impressive sight,   sir. Watching those relays wink   out one after another.
Sorry I missed it.
After that all we had to do was   sabotage the restart sequencers   and get out. Like I said, sir...   It was all by the numbers.
Are you sure this cadet is telling   the truth?
He admitted to committing acts of   treason against the Federation.   If he was going to lie, I think he   would've come up with a better   story.
I take it you gave him a blood   screening.
I checked him myself. He's human.

Well then let's say he's telling   the truth... that he was ordered   by his superiors to sabotage the   power relays. That still doesn't   rule out Dominion involvement.   For all we know, his superiors   have been replaced by changelings.
I thought about that. But if it   were changelings, what have they   accomplished? There's been no   invasion, power's been restored...
And Starfleet has fortified Earth.   I see your point, Captain.
So let's say you're right.   Starfleet officers sabotaged the   power grid. What are you going to   do about it?

That's the bottom line, isn't it?   What am I going to do about it?       These people aren't evil, Odo.   They're people I've worked with...   they're my friends... people I   respect. How can I turn against   them?
It seems to me, if they have   committed treason against the   Federation, the Federation you   swore to protect, then you won't   be turning against them... they'll   have turned against you.
Captain Sisko, Mister Odo, come   in.
Thank you for seeing us, Mister   President. I hope we didn't wake   you.
No. My people require very little   sleep.
Although I was working on a speech   I'm going to deliver to the   Federation Assembly, so if you   could make this brief...
Sir, what I'm about to say may   seem hard to believe. Frankly, I   have a difficult time accepting it   myself. Nevertheless --
I think we can do without the   preamble, Captain. Just tell me   what's on your mind.
Sir, I believe that certain   Starfleet officers, led by Admiral   Leyton, are conspiring to   overthrow the legitimate   government of the Federation.   and replace it with military rule.

Captain, I have been in politics   for seventy years. I'm no   stranger to overstatement and   exaggeration. But the idea that   Starfleet would plot to overthrow   the government of the Federation   is the single most astonishing   accusation I've ever heard.
Sir, if you'll hear us out...
Oh, I intend to, though you'll   have to forgive me if I remain   somewhat skeptical.       Now I think you'd better start   from the beginning.

Several months ago, I learned from   one of my people that changelings   had infiltrated the Federation.   Not long after I gave this   information to Starfleet, records   indicate that Admiral Leyton led   a contingent of high ranking   officers to meet with you and   recommend the implementation of   sweeping security measures meant   to protect Earth.
And I rejected their suggestions   as too extreme.
It's no secret that Leyton didn't   agree with you.
And despite your calls for calm,   his concern about the Dominion   threat continued to grow.
When the Antwerp Conference was   bombed, Leyton became convinced   that the changelings posed a much   greater threat to Earth than you   were prepared to admit.
And so the Admiral approached me   again. That time with you two at   his side. And I agreed to his   proposals.
To some of his proposals.

We believe that Admiral Leyton and   his supporters weren't satisfied   with the limited security   procedures you authorized. They   were convinced that extraordinary   measures were necessary to counter   the changeling threat.
More than that, they were   determined to prove to you and to   everyone else just how vulnerable   Earth was to a Dominion takeover.       So they sabotaged the global power   grid.
Starfleet officers committing   sabotage?
I know exactly how you feel. But   it's the truth.
I find that difficult to believe.   Admiral Leyton may be somewhat   grating and inflexible at times,   but for a man of his   accomplishments, of his   distinguished record... to commit   treason?
I'm sure the Admiral doesn't see   it as treason. He would probably   defend it as a desperate act of   patriotism. Leyton and his   supporters think their actions are   both necessary and justified.

Not to mention effective.       Think about it. The power grid   fails and the next thing you know,   there are Starfleet security   officers on the streets of every   city, armed with phaser rifles,   blood testing citizens at random.
Your story has a certain logic to   it, gentlemen. But what it lacks   so far is proof.
You want proof... Order Admiral   Leyton to withdraw his troops from   the streets... see what he does.
You think he would refuse a direct   order from his commander-in-chief?

If he orders his troops to stand   down, then I'm wrong and I'll   offer my resignation. But I don't   think that's going to happen.   With those troops in place,   Admiral Leyton controls Earth.   And he's not going to give up that   control until he's convinced he's   ended the Dominion threat.

And he may not have to give up   anything.       If what you say is true, if the   power outage was all part of   Leyton's plan, then it's worked   perfectly. Right now the public   overwhelmingly supports the   increased security. If I tried to   remove the troops, over Leyton's   objections, I'd have a planetwide   riot on my hands.
What if we bring you proof? Hard   evidence linking Leyton to the   sabotage of the power grid?
With that, you could force Leyton   to stand down, make him withdraw   the troops.
If what you say is true, I'll have   his resignation.       Bring me that evidence, and I   promise you, I'll use it.
Cadet Shepard should've been here   twenty minutes ago.
I told Nog to make sure no one saw   them leave the Academy. With the   added security in place, I'm sure   that wasn't easy.
What if they got caught?
Nog spent his entire adolescence   dodging you on the Promenade. If   anyone can sneak out of that place   it's him.
I suppose so. I doubt there's   ever been a cadet in Starfleet who   was quite so... slippery.
Sorry I'm late...
Where's Cadet Shepherd?
That's a good question. I   couldn't find him anywhere.
What do you mean, you couldn't   find him?
I mean he's gone. And as far as   I can tell so is every other   member of Red Squad. The rumor is   they've all been sent on some kind   of training exercise.
I'm afraid Cadet Shepherd won't be   returning to Earth anytime soon.
Admiral Leyton, it's an honor to   meet you. My name is --
Return to your quarters, cadet.
Ben, I think you and I need to   talk.       In private.
I'll be in the next room if you   need me.
Mind if I get some coffee?
Help yourself.
I haven't been getting a lot of   sleep lately. Too much to do.
Maybe you need a vacation.
Mmm. Somehow replicated coffee   never tastes this good.
I'm afraid I owe you an apology,   Ben.
The way I see it, you owe a lot of   people an apology.
I wish I could've told you the   truth from the beginning. But   somehow I suspected we wouldn't   see eye-to-eye on this thing.
Then why did you bring me here?

Because I needed someone who knew   how to fight Shape-shifters. And   that's you.       And I suppose on some level I   hoped that once you saw what we   were accomplishing, you'd join us.       You always had a strong sense of   duty.
My duty is to protect the   Federation.
Which is what we're trying to do.
What you're trying to do is seize   control of Earth and place it   under military rule.
If that's what it takes to stop   the Dominion.
You're willing to destroy paradise   in order to save it.

Do you remember when we were on   the Okinawa fighting the   Tzenkethi? That time when I   wanted to take the ship into an   asteroid belt to chase down those   three raiders. We talked it over   at the staff meeting...
And I said it was an unnecessary   risk.

You spoke your mind. Which is   exactly what a good executive   officer is supposed to do. But I   overruled you.       After the staff meeting you   followed me into my ready room and   tried to argue your point again.
That's right, I did.
And remember what I told you?

That a good officer has to respect   the chain of command. There comes   a time when you have to accept the   orders of a superior officer and   carry out his orders, whether you   agree with them or not.
I also told you when you became a   C.O., you'd feel the same way.
And you were right. About going   after the Tzenkethi and about me.

Without the chain of command,   Starfleet would cease to function   and we wouldn't stand a chance   against our enemies.       I'm still your commanding officer.   And now more than ever, I need you   to respect my authority.
I can't do that. Not this time.
Then as of now, I'm relieving you   of your post as temporary head of   Earth Security and sending you   back to Deep Space Nine.       Go home, Ben. You don't belong   here.
Beautiful evening, isn't it?
Chief? How'd you get here?
You know, you don't look so good.   Lot on your mind, I bet? How's   your father?
There's no way the Defiant   could've gotten here so soon.
I didn't say I came on the   Defiant.       Tell me the truth. Do you really   think phaser rifles will do any   good against...       ... Shape-shifters?
You're not O'Brien.
Luckily, no. The thought of being   locked in one shape all of the   time... it's not natural.
Don't bother calling for help. It   would only cut our conversation   short. And I do enjoy your   company.
If you have something to say to   me... say it.
You solids. You're so impatient.   I thought we could sit here for a   while, maybe go to a bar, have a   pint, throw some darts.
I don't think so.
Let me ask you a question. How   many changelings do you think are   here on Earth right at this   moment?
I'm not going to play guessing   games with you.
What if I told you there are only   four on this entire planet, not   counting Constable Odo of course.   Think of it. Only four of us, and   look at the havoc we've wrought.
How do I know you're telling the   truth?
Four's more than enough. We're   smarter than solids... we're   better than you... and most   importantly, we don't fear you the   way you fear us. In the end, it's   your fear that will destroy you.
Are you finished?
Finished?       We've barely begun.
Be seeing you.
I recognize that look.
scene: OA   INT. SISKO'S CREOLE KITCHEN - NIGHT

quote: What look is that?
scene: OA   INT. SISKO'S CREOLE KITCHEN - NIGHT

quote: The one you're wearing. The one   that says, "Something's bothering   me and I don't know what to do   about it."
scene: OA   INT. SISKO'S CREOLE KITCHEN - NIGHT

quote: Oh. That look.
scene: OA   INT. SISKO'S CREOLE KITCHEN - NIGHT

quote: You want to tell me about it?
scene: OA   INT. SISKO'S CREOLE KITCHEN - NIGHT

quote: I wish I could.
scene: OA   INT. SISKO'S CREOLE KITCHEN - NIGHT

quote: Oh, I see. It's a Neffie Beumont   kind of thing.
scene: OA   INT. SISKO'S CREOLE KITCHEN - NIGHT

quote: Neffie Beumont. Did I ever have   a crush on her.
scene: OA   INT. SISKO'S CREOLE KITCHEN - NIGHT

quote: Not that you'd admit it. You just sat   around for weeks, brooding and   pining away. Trying to sort it   all out. Until your old man   finally sat you down one day and   gave you some advice.
scene: OA   INT. SISKO'S CREOLE KITCHEN - NIGHT

quote: "There comes a time in every man's   life when he's got to stop   thinking and start doing."
scene: OA   INT. SISKO'S CREOLE KITCHEN - NIGHT

quote: And the next day, you finally went   over to young Neffie's house and   asked her out.
scene: OA   INT. SISKO'S CREOLE KITCHEN - NIGHT

quote: And she turned me down.
scene: OA   INT. SISKO'S CREOLE KITCHEN - NIGHT

quote: But at least you weren't brooding   anymore. And when Zoey Phillips   moved into the neighborhood a few   weeks later, you asked her out   before her parents were done   beaming in the furniture.
scene: OA   INT. SISKO'S CREOLE KITCHEN - NIGHT

quote: And we dated for three years.
scene: OA   INT. SISKO'S CREOLE KITCHEN - NIGHT

quote: So what you're trying to say is   stop brooding and make a decision.
scene: OA   INT. SISKO'S CREOLE KITCHEN - NIGHT

quote: Exactly.
scene: OA   INT. SISKO'S CREOLE KITCHEN - NIGHT

quote: Thanks, Dad.
scene: OA   INT. SISKO'S CREOLE KITCHEN - NIGHT

quote: Don't mention it.
scene: OA   INT. SISKO'S CREOLE KITCHEN - NIGHT

quote: Make sure you turn out the lights   on the way out.       I wonder what ever happened to   Zoey Phillips?
scene: OA   INT. SISKO'S CREOLE KITCHEN - NIGHT

quote: Captain, why are you transmitting   on a Bajoran frequency?
scene: 16   INT. SISKO'S CREOLE KITCHEN - NIGHT - LATER (OPTICAL)

quote: Let's just say, there are things   we need to discuss that I don't   want anyone else to hear.       What's your status?
scene: 16   INT. SISKO'S CREOLE KITCHEN - NIGHT - LATER (OPTICAL)

quote: Everything here is fine. There's   no sign of Dominion activity.
scene: 16   INT. SISKO'S CREOLE KITCHEN - NIGHT - LATER (OPTICAL)

quote: What about the wormhole?
scene: 16   INT. SISKO'S CREOLE KITCHEN - NIGHT - LATER (OPTICAL)

quote: It's acting normally again. It   stopped opening and closing at   random not long after you left.
scene: 16   INT. SISKO'S CREOLE KITCHEN - NIGHT - LATER (OPTICAL)

quote: And if any Dominion ships did   sneak through, they haven't given   us any trouble.
scene: 16   INT. SISKO'S CREOLE KITCHEN - NIGHT - LATER (OPTICAL)

quote: Listen closely, both of you.   There's something I need you to   do...
scene: 16   INT. SISKO'S CREOLE KITCHEN - NIGHT - LATER (OPTICAL)

quote: It's all yours. And I suggest you   hurry. I doubt it will take them   very long to discover we're here.
I never knew it was so easy to   break into classified Starfleet   files.
Everything I know I learned from   Quark.
It looks like Leyton's been a busy   man. He's personally reassigned   over four hundred officers in the   past three weeks.
Do you recognize any of these   names?

A lot of them. Daneeka, McWatt,   Snowden, Orr, Moodus, they were   all officers on the Okinawa when   I was Leyton's X.O.       As far as I can tell, every   officer on this list served under   Leyton at one time or another.
And now they're all in key   positions here on Earth.
Or commanding ships somewhere in   this sector.       It says here he's authorized   another set of transfers. Take a   look at these dates.
They all go into effect on the   fourteenth.
The day before the President's   speech.
Do you think there's a connection?
Maybe Admiral Leyton doesn't   intend for the President to make   that speech.       We'd better get a copy of this.
Odo, if Leyton is planning some   kind of takeover on the   fourteenth, I want to make sure   that Jake and my father are safe.
We should get them off Earth as   soon as possible.
I want you to go to New Orleans.   Get them on a transport to Mars.   I've got a lot of friends at the   Planetia shipyards. Jake and my   father'll be safe there.
Come in.
Captain. I'm surprised to find   you here.
Just cleaning out my files.       I'll see you later, Constable.
Good night, Captain.
I hear congratulations are in   order.
Your promotion. Captain of the   Lakota.
Thanks. But it's still a few days   away. The Lakota won't be done   with its refit until the   fourteenth.
I guess that'll make the   fourteenth a special day.
I'm looking forward to it.      Too bad you won't be around for   the ceremony.
Who knows? I might be able to fit   it in.
I thought Admiral Leyton ordered   you back to Deep Space Nine.

He did. But I've got some leave   coming, and I've decided to take   it. After all, I don't get to   spend much time on Earth.       And it's so pleasant here. With   a Starfleet officer on every   corner. Paradise has never seemed   so... well-armed.
You're a very interesting man,   captain. I'm sorry we didn't get   to work together longer.
Maybe you should think about   vacationing someplace else. I   hear Risal's nice this time of   year.
I was wondering when you'd get   back.
Take a seat. I made you some eggs   and a cup of raktajino. Extra   strong the way you like it.
Jake, what are you doing here?   You're supposed to be on your way   to the Planetia Yards.
The shuttle doesn't leave for   another two hours. I figured you   could use some breakfast.
Where's Grandpa and Odo?
They're waiting for me at   Bracketville Spaceport.       Which brings up an interesting   question... Why's it so important   that we leave Earth?
You're just going to have to trust   me on this one.
I do. But I want you to know...   I'm not a kid anymore. If you   need my help, I'm here for you.
I know that. And I appreciate it.   But right now, there isn't a whole   lot you can do.       Except take care of Grandpa for   me.
You know I'll do that.
Then I guess you'd better get over   to Bracketville. You've got a   shuttle to catch.
How are the eggs?
Pretty damn good.
I got the recipe from Grandpa.
Captain Sisko to see you.
Let him in.
Admiral. I didn't expect to see   you here.
I'm sure you didn't.
Captain, your arm please?
Do as she asks.
Just as I said, Mister President.   He's a Shape-shifter.
You can wait outside.
scene: 29   INT. STARFLEET HEADQUARTERS - SECURITY CELLS - DAY

quote: Are you going to tell me how you   faked the blood test?
scene: 29   INT. STARFLEET HEADQUARTERS - SECURITY CELLS - DAY

quote: Does it matter?
scene: 29   INT. STARFLEET HEADQUARTERS - SECURITY CELLS - DAY

quote: I suppose not.
scene: 29   INT. STARFLEET HEADQUARTERS - SECURITY CELLS - DAY

quote: You know, Ben, I stand here   looking at you, the best officer   who ever served under me, trapped   in that holding cell, and I   think... life can be damn cruel.
scene: 29   INT. STARFLEET HEADQUARTERS - SECURITY CELLS - DAY

quote: Let me out. Maybe life'll look a   little better.
scene: 29   INT. STARFLEET HEADQUARTERS - SECURITY CELLS - DAY

quote: I don't think I can do that just   now.
scene: 29   INT. STARFLEET HEADQUARTERS - SECURITY CELLS - DAY

quote: So what are you going to do? Keep   me here forever?
scene: 29   INT. STARFLEET HEADQUARTERS - SECURITY CELLS - DAY

quote: You'll be free to go in a few   days.
scene: 29   INT. STARFLEET HEADQUARTERS - SECURITY CELLS - DAY

quote: Let me guess. After the   President's speech.
scene: 29   INT. STARFLEET HEADQUARTERS - SECURITY CELLS - DAY

quote: The President won't be making a   speech. I will.
scene: 29   INT. STARFLEET HEADQUARTERS - SECURITY CELLS - DAY

quote: I assume you'll be explaining to   the public why it's necessary for   Starfleet to seize control of   Earth.
scene: 29   INT. STARFLEET HEADQUARTERS - SECURITY CELLS - DAY

quote: Temporarily, of course. Until the   changeling threat has been   neutralized.
scene: 29   INT. STARFLEET HEADQUARTERS - SECURITY CELLS - DAY

quote: And how long will that be?   Months? Years? Decades?
scene: 29   INT. STARFLEET HEADQUARTERS - SECURITY CELLS - DAY

quote: However long it takes.       The people deserve strong   leadership. Someone who can   protect them.
scene: 29   INT. STARFLEET HEADQUARTERS - SECURITY CELLS - DAY

quote: In other words... you.
scene: 29   INT. STARFLEET HEADQUARTERS - SECURITY CELLS - DAY

quote: If you need anything... food,   something to read, just tell the   guards.
scene: 29   INT. STARFLEET HEADQUARTERS - SECURITY CELLS - DAY

quote: Well, if it isn't my favorite   vampire.
Vampires only come out at night.   I've been pushing this cart all   day.
I'm getting a little tired of all   these blood screenings.
Believe me, I'm just as tired of   giving them as you are of taking   them.
(calling out from his    cell)   Why don't you give me one of those   while you're at it?
You don't really expect me to let   down that forcefield and go in   there with you.
He's not the one you should be   worried about. I am.
Nicely done, Constable.
It wasn't that difficult. After   all I did help you revise the   security measures for this   building.
Lucky for me. Have you contacted   Kira?
The Defiant is on its way to   Earth.
They found what we were looking   for.
It was just as you suspected.   They even found the officer   responsible. Lieutenant Arriaga.   They've got him on the Defiant.
You have to get to the President.   Tell him everything we know. And   warn him that Leyton's going to   make his move sometime today.
What about you?
I have some business to take care   of.
Good luck, Captain Benteen.   Leyton out.
Are you planning on using that?
Against a fellow officer? I hope   not.       But I willhave to ask for your   resignation.
You'll forgive me if I don't leap   at the opportunity.
I've got enough evidence to   convict you of treason.
Do you?

We have Lieutenant Arriaga in   custody. He's prepared to admit   that on your orders, he attached   a subspace modulator to the relay   satellite on the far side of the   wormhole. That's why it was   opening and closing at random.
Why would anyone want to do that?
To make it look like a cloaked   Dominion fleet was entering   Federation space. That way when   Earth's power relays were   sabotaged, people would think that   an invasion was imminent.
That's a very interesting theory,   but it's not going to do you much   good. Lieutenant Arriaga. isn't   going to get to Earth.       I've sent the Lakota to intercept   the Defiant.
Do you really think one Starfleet   ship will fire on another?
As far as Captain Benteen's crew   is concerned, the Defiant isn't a   Starfleet ship. They've been told   everyone on the Defiant's been   replaced by Shape-shifters.
Commander, we're being hailed by   the Lakota. They're ordering us   to drop out of warp, and prepare   to be boarded.
They've raised their shields and   powered up their phasers.       Looks like they won't take no for   an answer.
Admiral, don't you realize what's   going on here? Even if you win,   even if you do manage to oust   Jaresh-Inyo, you still lose. We   all lose.
I can't say I agree with you.
Do you think the other Federation   worlds are going to sit back and   let their President be replaced by   a military dictatorship?
Hardly a dictatorship, Ben.

Overthrowing a legitimately   elected President and giving   Starfleet direct control over   the government? Sounds like a   dictatorship to me. And I'm sure   I won't be the only one who thinks   so.
There'll be some dissenters at   first. But they'll fall in line   once they realize strengthening   Earth is the first step toward   strengthening the Federation.
And if they don't agree, what   then? Are you willing to risk   civil war?       If the Lakota fires on the   Defiant, you'll be opening a   Pandora's Box that may never be   closed.
Then contact the Defiant and tell   them to stand down.
I won't do that.
I didn't think so. But don't kid   yourself, Ben... this Pandora's   Box of yours, we're opening it   together.
The Lakota's targeting its weapons   on our warp engines.
They're bluffing. That's a   Federation ship. They're not   going to fire on us.
I hope you're right, Chief.
Continue on course.
We're in weapons range.
Raise shields.
Damage report.
Port shields are at sixty percent.
Someone's been upgrading the   Lakota's weapons. That's a lot of   firepower for an Excelsior-class   ship.
Can we cloak?
We would have to lower our   shields.
I wouldn't advise it.
Do we make a run for it?
If they've been tinkering with the   weapons, who knows what they've   done to their warp drive.
Hail them.
No answer.
They're trying to disable our   engines.
Let's go. We'd better get you to   the Medical Bay.
What do we do, Commander?
We fight.
Target their weapons. Fire   phasers.
Want some? It's Bolian tonic   water. Calms the nerves.
No thank you.

Ironic, isn't it? When you came   on board the Okinawa, you were   more interested in engineering and   ship design than command. But I   promoted you to lieutenant   commander, gave you the post of   executive officer, and taught you   everything I knew about being a   leader.
You were a good teacher.
I wish I'd taught you more about   the importance of loyalty.

You want to talk to me about   loyalty? After you broke your   oath to the Federation, lied to   the people of Earth, and ordered   one of our starships to fire on   another? You don't have the   right.
You don't understand me at all, do   you?
I used to think I did. I thought   you were a man of principles, a   man of honor. I see now, I was   mistaken.
I'm sorry you feel that way.
So am I.
Admiral, we're receiving a message   from the Lakota.
Put it through.
We haven't been able to stop the   Defiant. Someone's equipped her   with ablative armor and neglected   to inform Starfleet operations.
Under no circumstances is that   ship to reach Earth.       The Lakota's carrying quantum   torpedoes, isn't she?
Yes, sir.
Then use them.
Admiral, my orders were to disable   the Defiant, not destroy her.
Your orders are to keep the   Defiant from reaching Earth by any   means necessary. Is that   understood?
Yes, it is.
Captain, you know as well as I do   that there aren't any   Shape-shifters on the Defiant. Use   those quantum torpedoes and you'll   be killing fifty Starfleet officers.
Captain Benteen knows where her   duty lies.       You have your orders.
Yes, sir.
Shields are almost gone. We have   major systems failures on decks   one, three and four.
What about the Lakota?
They're in worse shape.       One good hit would probably finish   them off.
And kill everyone on board.
That is not an option.
It's either them or us.
Mister Worf, I think you should   look at this.
They've powered down their   weapons.       Hold your fire.
They're hailing us.
On screen.
Admiral Leyton, we are receiving   a message for Captain Sisko, from   the Defiant.
Put it through.
Do as he says.
Captain, I apologize for the   delay.
What's your status, Mister Worf?
The Lakota has powered down its   weapons and is allowing us to   proceed to Earth.
Casualties?
Bartlett and Ramsey are dead, sir.   Seven more seriously injured.   Captain Benteen thinks there may   have been as many as two dozen   casualties on the Lakota.
Get here as soon as you can. The   President's expecting you.
Aye, sir.
That was a mistake, Ben... talking   to your ship from my office. Now   that security knows you're here,   you'll never make it past that   door.
It doesn't matter whether I make   it out of here or not.
By now, Odo is talking to Jaresh-   Inyo. The President will have the   evidence he needs to stop you.   It's over.
It's not over. I have enough   loyal officers to make a fight of   it.

Who will you fight? Starfleet?   the Federation? Don't you see,   Admiral? You're fighting the   wrong war.       And as far as your loyal officers   are concerned, Benteen's already   abandoned you. And she was closer   to you than anyone.
You've lost. Don't make anyone   else pay for your mistakes.
I hope you're not the one making   the mistake.
The streets are going to seem   emptier with them gone.
Would you be happier if they'd   stayed?
If they had stayed, it wouldn't be   Earth anymore, would it? It   didn't seem right, all those   phasers everywhere.
Something wrong, Odo?
Am I the only one worried that   there are still changelings here   on Earth?
Worried? I'm scared to death.   But I'll be damned if I'm going to   let them change the way I live my   life.
If the changelings want to destroy   what we've built here, they'll   have to do it themselves. We're   not going to do it for them.
I'm going to miss you, Son.
You, too, Jake-O.       Feels like you just got here.
You sure I can't convince you to   come back to the station with us?
A Creole restaurant would be a big   hit on the Promenade.
Then you'll just have to open one.   This is my home.
We'd better get going. Now don't   forget to take --
To take my medicine. I know.       Is he always such a mother hen?
He means well.
Take care of yourself. And try   not to worry so much.
I'll do my best.
That's all I can ask.
Three to beam up.
Well, what are you waiting for?   Have a seat. Today I'm   recommending the pasta boudin...   It's got a bit of a kick but it'll   make you smile.
